_exec_summary.SummaryText:
REGISTRATION INFORMATION

The Pfizer Global Manufacturing (Pfizer), Holland Site, manufactures a variety of life-saving and life-enhancing pharmaceuticals at its facility located at 188 Howard Avenue, Holland, Michigan.  Pfizer uses one chemical that is regulated by the EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) rules (40 CFR Part 68).  This chemical is phosgene which is also regulated by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119).

Pfizer has always acknowledged its civic responsibility to provide its colleagues and the residents of the Holland community with a safe facility.  Pfizer strives to meet or exceed applicable EPA and OSHA rules and regulations, and periodically evaluates the quality of its environmental and safety programs.  The facility?s accident prevention and emergency response procedures have been designed to protect our colleagues, the community and environment, and Pfizer properties, to the greatest extent possible.  Pfizer maintains extensive on-site emergency response equipment and trained personnel, and has integrated its emergency response procedures with those of the Holland Township Fire Department and the Ottawa County Local Emergency Planning Committee.

The designated representative and contact person for environmental matters and this Risk Management Plan at the Pfizer facility is Mr. Scott Befus, Director of Environmental, Health & Safety.  He can be contacted at the facility at (616) 392-2375, Ext. 2529.

SUBSTANCE PROPERTIES

Phosgene is a toxic and corrosive liquid.  Phosgene evaporates to form a gas at temperatures above the boiling point.  Exposure may cause severe irritation to the respiratory system, skin and eyes.  Inhalation of high concentrations of phosgene may cause headache, olfactory fatigue, respiratory irritation, difficulty breathing, lung congestion and, under extreme conditions, death.  In addition, symptoms may be delayed for a period of from 24 to 48 hours after exposure.  It is critical that perso

ns exposed to phosgene seek immediate medical attention for prompt treatment. 

RELEASE SCENARIOS

The EPA rules required the development of worst-case release scenarios that assume the entire contents of the largest container of a highly hazardous chemical are released in ten minutes under adverse weather conditions.  Pfizer developed a worst case release scenario for phosgene based on the maximum quantity contained within one cylinder.  The worst case modeling was conducted using the EPA approved SLAB model for dense gases.  Model results are contained in the checklist portion of this plan.
 
Public and environmental receptors are located within the radius of the worst-case release scenario.  These receptors include homes; small businesses; commercial, office and industrial areas; schools; a hospital; a jail, churches; public parks and recreational areas.   Pfizer believes that the EPA defined worst case phosgene scenario can not occur due to the high level of phosgene process safety and the associated Pfizer process safety management and emergency response programs . 

The alternative case modeling was conducted using the EPA approved SLAB model for dense gases. Model results are contained in the checklist portion of this plan.  Public and environmental receptors are located within the radius of the alternative release scenario.  These receptors include homes; small businesses; commercial, office and industrial areas; schools; churches; public parks and recreational areas.   

The described alternative release scenario is extremely conservative.  Pfizer believes that the defined scenario for phosgene is highly unlikely to occur due to the high level of process safety and the associated Pfizer process safety management and emergency response programs. Pfizer believes that any phosgene release would have substantially less impact on potential environmental and public receptors than the described alternative scenario.  

ACCIDENT HISTORY

Pfizer has not experienced

any accident from a regulated process in the last five years that resulted in on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property or environmental damage.  

LEVEL 3 PREVENTION PROGRAM

Pfizer maintains a Process Safety Management program that contains all OSHA required elements including process hazards analysis, colleague training, contractor qualification and control, preventative maintenance, and change control.  

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

Pfizer maintains a comprehensive emergency response program that includes colleague response to fire, hazardous materials release, colleague rescue and first aid.  Pfizer maintains a written Emergency Response Plan describing facility evacuation and emergency response programs and procedures.  Specific emergency response actions have been defined for phosgene. 

Pfizer maintains a good relationship with the Holland Township fire department and works closely with the Ottawa County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  The LEPC has an emergency response plan for the Pfizer site.
